Reduces variance, so has a strong beneficial effect on high variance classifiers.
We can obtain a mean score and

as the prediction is an average of many classifiers. Variance can be interpreted as the uncertainty of the prediction.  Especially in regression tasks, such uncertainties are otherwise hard to obtain. For example, imagine the prediction of a house price is  $300,000. If a buyer wants to decide how much to offer, it would be very valuable to know if this prediction has standard deviation  +-$10,000 or +-$50,000.
Bagging provides an unbiased estimate of the test error- the
. The idea is that for each training point, there are very likely to be some data sets

children.html: DkD_kDk​

children.value: that did not pick this point. If we average the classifiers

children.html: hkh_khk​

children.value: of all such data sets, we obtain a classifier that was not trained on

children.html: (xi,yi)(\mathbf{x}_i,y_i)(xi​,yi​)

children.value: ever. To these classifiers, this point is equivalent to a test sample. If we compute the error of all these points, we obtain an estimate of the true test error.

children.value: Decision trees do not require a lot of preprocessing, so the features can be of different scale, magnitude, or slope. This is highly advantageous with heterogeneous data, for example with features like blood pressure, age, gender, ... each of which is recorded in completely different units.
Split each training set into two partitions

Do not grow each tree to its full depth, instead prune based on the leave out samples. This can further improve your bias/variance trade-off. (An easy way to prune decision trees is to start from the bottom and then to remove splits and check to see if it affects our error too much. If it doesn’t we remove that split.)
